messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] i know you must have been asked this many times
messages.msgSnippet: Are you the person who desires to be unschooled, or the parent of kids whom you desire to unschool? ... From: kbcdlovejo@aol.com  To:
messages.messageBody:
Are you the person who desires to be unschooled, or the parent of kids whom you desire to unschool?


----- Original Message ----
From: "kbcdlovejo@..." <kbcdlovejo@...>
To: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 12, 2007 9:17:58 AM
Subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] i know you must have been asked this many times


-----Original Message-----
From: japaneseprint@ yahoo.com

i've been putting together another, more in-depth proposal for my
parents, but do you have any other suggestions so my parents will
agree to unschooling?

-=-=-

Have they read John Taylor Gatto's Dumbing Us Down or The Underground
History of American Education?

That might be a good way to get them on board.

~Kelly

Kelly Lovejoy
Conference Coordinator
Live and Learn Unschooling Conference
http://www.LiveandL earnConference. org

____________ _________ _________ _________ _________ _________ _
AOL now offers free email to everyone. Find out more about what's free
from AOL at AOL.com.

messages.subject: i know you must have been asked this many times
messages.msgSnippet: hi. i am new here, as you can tell, and i am interested in unschooling. i was first interested in it after reading the teenage liberation handbook this past
messages.messageBody:
hi.
i am new here, as you can tell, and i am interested in unschooling.
i was first interested in it after reading "the teenage liberation
handbook" this past fall. i, in my excitment, threw together a
proposal and showed it to my parents.

of course, they were completely against the idea. with my
suggestion, they read "the teenage liberation handbook", let the
idea mull over for a couple weeks and again said no. but instead of
sending me back to public school that year, i ended in a liberal
private school for my first year of highschool.

as the year is winding down, i have looked into the topic of
unschooling again because my school is very dissatisfying
academically (it's been two trimesters and i think i've learned
about three things). i don't want to go back to my old public school
where i learned more but the only things on students minds are sex,
drugs, and cheerleading/football. i also don't want to go to a
preppy private school. so, unschooling seems like the best choice
out of my options so far.

i've been putting together another, more in-depth proposal for my
parents, but do you have any other suggestions so my parents will
agree to unschooling?

thanks,
japaneseprint.
